captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. So we need
to talk about your last Vlogbrothers video,

and not the one where the Gregory Brothers
songified our fight about Batman, the one

before that where you talked about... I actually
don't remember what you talked about because

I was too focused on this. So Hank, Nerdfighter
reviews of your new hair cut were universally

positive, but then again, Nerdfighteria is
a very supportive and loving community, whereas
I am your brother.

Hank, in my my life I've had three major hair
styles. For about the past fifteen years I've

had some variation of short on the sides,
messy up top. Before that, for many years

I had a hair cut called "The Junior Senator
from Maryland" and then of course there was

my original hair cut "Toad from Mario Kart."
Meanwhile Hank, your entire life you've had

just the one hair style, which I call The
Hank, I can't even describe the exact properties

of The Hank to you because it just is. It's
like trying to describe water to a fish. "The

Hank" is that which sits atop Hank's head.
And then suddenly, change! Unannounced, radical
change!

Now Hank as you know, I'm not a huge fan of
change. I just think change is tremendously

overrated. People are always like: "Life is
change!" And that's true, but you know what

else is change? Death. But Hank, your hairstyle
change upset me particularly because it reminded

me a little bit of Kennedy's haircut. You
know, the left-back of the AFC Wimbledon Wimbly

Womblys, the fictional soccer team I play
FIFA 14 with.

Now Hank I realize when it comes to hair I
live in the glassiest of glass houses, but

I've been throwing rocks at Kennedy's hair
for years now. And then, suddenly, my own

brother adopts a version of The Kennedy. Well
Hank, this led to a bit of an existential

crisis. Now Hank, admittedly, these days it
doesn't take much to point me in the direction

of an existential crisis, but I started thinking
about my brother, who is a real person in

real life I really like, and then there's
Kennedy, a very talented, but fictional, left-back

who's technically made out of pixels. But
now in my head they're connected, so anything

I say about Kennedy's hair I'm sort of implying
about your hair.

And the whole thing just made me think about
how nothing that happened in one's so called

"virtual life" could ever be fully disconnected
from what happens in your so called "real

life", right? I think realness might be more
of like a continuum than an actual thing,

you know? Like ultimately, self-hood and relationships
and experiences and FIFA playing and whatever

else are varying degrees of real rather than
simply real or not.

Like Hank, in my life there are two AFC Wimbledons,
right? There are the AFC Wimbledon Wimbly

Womblys a fictional FIFA team who have worked
their way up from League Two and are now enjoying

their first season in the Premier League,
and it's going great because Bald John Green

and Other John Green, our two strikers, have
found renewed form since the adoption of their

baby boy JJ. And that whole Wimbly Wombly
world is to quote Severus Snape "Real for

Us", us being the weird and lovely people
who support the Wimbly Womblys. And then we

use the ad revenue from that series to sponsor
the other AFC Wimbledon, you know, the real

one. That AFC Wimbledon is an actual professional
Soccer team in England, but it started 13

years ago from nothing except a bunch of fans
who had the idea to make a soccer team.

The fact that imagination and work can make
ideas real is what finally resolved this existential

crisis, because it's like the most beautiful
and lovely thing about life to me. The whole

thing just made me want to support AFC Wimbledon
more if we can, so I'm gonna try to do more

video gaming stuff. I've, started a Twitch
TV channel, and even though I don't really

know how it works I'm gonna try broadcasting
today. There's a link in the doobly-doo.

So basically Hank, your new haircut made me
think about what's real and what's not real

and how much I admire people like you and
the founders of AFC Wimbledon for working

so hard to make awesome things real. And then
I was like, you know what? I kind of like

Hank's new haircut, which, by extension means
that I guess now I kinda like Kennedy's haircut

in FIFA. This was a very weird Vlogbrothers
video. I will see you on Friday.

title: Hank's Haircut and Related Existential Crises

brother's new haircut, the natural result of that is wanting to support a 
soccer team. ﻿

comments.author: Ysabelle Icaro

comments.text:
All I can think about this is that John is like . . . this man--this person 
who in his teenage years went off and explored abandoned buildings, and 
went on long road trips, and smoked on swing sets, and missed English class 
despite his teachers thinking he had potential. And through all his 
adventures, he saw people in his mind with him--young, adventurous, 
different--and he saw them living in the same world he was. And he wrote 
about them, though different from who he is or the real characters in his 
life. But he wrote them in the same frame of the world he knows. And maybe 
he wrote them, because he can control them. He can control Margo Roth 
Spiegelman's adventures, and he can control Augustus Waters' non-smoking 
habits, as well as the timing of his cancer. But he couldn't really control 
his life or his adventures, because all he was was a man of imagination and 
creativity and ideas. But he grew up with the people around him, like his 
brother--no, especially his brother--who seemed to know how to control the 
rest of the world. His brother could take an idea for environmental 
advocacies, and make a website. His brother could take an idea, and sketch 
it out on paper to be visible. His brother could make music, videos, 
shirts, designs, whatever. His brother could make conventions, and a music 
label, and everything else. While John is here, walking on his treadmill, 
typing up words, because that's all he has. John is here, playing 
videogames of a fictional football team. And the rest of the world gets to 
make things real. When he made something outside of his books or his 
fictional team (let's say, when he and the Yeti made real kids, as an 
example) John wishes he could control people. But he can't. He can't 
program the very interesting, different ways Henry has managed to see the 
world, and he can only witness the way he can't control him. So this 
specific moment where the one thing that doesn't seem to change despite him 
not making some active way of controlling it--Hank's hair cut--finally 
does? That's it. He doesn't understand reality anymore, because his brother 
got a hair cut.

Also, that hair cut looks really, really good on Hank. I haven't been 
watching much, and I saw it just today, and wow. Hank looks really good.

Also maybe John is used to being the more likeable brother? More 
good-looking between the two? Maybe he's just not used to Hank being 
uncomfortably near his level right now? ????﻿

called the Velveteen Rabbit. Watching this episode reminded me of this book 
in its ideas about reality, and what makes real things real, and how 
'imaginary' things can become real through the caring of people. I don't 
know if you have ever read that book, of if you ever take video 
suggestions, or if you will even read this comment- but I would love to 
hear your thoughts relating to The Velveteen Rabbit 😄.﻿

Thank you for existing. As I sit in my tiny apartment (it's a step to tiny 
house!) planning, testing, and teaching Principles of Modern Activism to my 
well... I guess they are my followers? They call themselves the knights to 
my King Arthur, the princesses to my Fairy Goddess Mother-ness. As I sit 
here I am also battling with undiagnosed mental illness and you made me 
laugh so hard over being easily pointed towards an existential crisis. 
Truth my friend. Again, thank you!﻿

comments.author: Celi Méndez

comments.text:
I just read Paper Towns today, (Yes, the whole thing in one day) and I 
thought "oh this is such a fun story about this nervous guy who gets to go 
on an adventure with his childhood sweetheart and oh yeah this is so 
great," but my goodness. When I got to the end just an hour ago, I was on 
the verge of tears. This is incredible story, the way that you (John) tied 
everything up from the beginning to the end, and the way that Q did 
everything he could to look for clues to find Margo, even the clues that 
weren't there was so beautiful. Then the way that you (John) talked about 
the different ways one could look at death and the future the grass or the 
strings really just touched me. Thank you (John) so much for creating this 
incredible journey for me. I don't care if anyone sees this but I just 
really needed to say it. ﻿

comments.text:
Here's some food for thought, John: If the world is made of degrees of 
realness, then you are a higher degree of real to yourself than you are to 
your friends and family, but you are a higher degree of real to your 
friends and family than you are to the people who have only ever seen you 
on a youtube video. You are also real-er to all of these people than to 
those who have only seen your name on the cover of that book everyone's 
been talking about.

Cheers.﻿
